prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This face-on disk has very narrow lines, with FWHM < 1 km/s. The requested spectral channel spacing of 0.15 km/s allows a few resolution elements per line. Higher resolution is not useful due to signal to noise issues, and with a lower resolution we would not resolve the line at all. If necessary, spectral binning can help to increase S/N. The bandwidth is sufficient to see the narrow line and the line-free continuum.

The angular resolution of 0.41'' (23au at 56pc) allows the CO freezeout zone to be distinguished from the inner disk, where CO does not freeze out. Other observations place the CO freezeout at 30au radius, so the CO evaporation region is resolved. Where CO evaporates, we expect a higher elemental carbon abundance. The largest angular scale (5.5'') is based on the size of the CO disk as seen with ALMA and on our best-fit models (Kama et al. submitted).

There is a single-dish flux measurement of the [CI] line from this source. Using the known disk radius of ~4'' and the 0.4'' beam size, we estimated a typical flux density of 63 mJy/beam (note in Figure 1 this is scaled from 56pc to a distance of 140pc). The requested 15 mJy/beam will allow at least 4-sigma detections typically.

The requested channel spacing of 0.15 km/s will sufficiently resolve the FWHM > 5 km/s lines of these inclined disks such that the velocity structures can be reconstructed and used as additional constraints when modelling the systems.

The angular resolution (0.51'') corresponds to ~70au at the Taurus distance (140pc), and this offers a few resolution elements across the disk. Most importantly, we can distinguish the CI emission from the cold outer disk (>50-100au radial distance) from the inner region. The largest angular scale corresponds to the estimated sizes of the disks.

Both targets here are early-type stars and the requested sensitivity is based on generic models for their disks. The requested sensitivity is such that a nominal carbon abundance will yield roughly a S/N=10 detection, while a strong carbon underabundance will yield important upper limits.

The requested channel spacing of 0.15 km/s will sufficiently resolve the FWHM > 5 km/s linewidth in this inclined disk, such that the velocity structure can be used as additional constraint when modelling the system. For DM Tau, in particular, a previously claimed single-dish detection is suspiciously narrow compared to the double-peaked CO lines and likely originates in a remnant envelope or disk wind, so velocity resolution is important as a double-check on the kinematics of the emitting gas. ALMA will filter out possible contamination, suspected from single-disk observations on scales substantially larger than the disk.

The angular resolution will allow to map the [CI] emission across this disk and search for trends of the elemental abundance as a function of radius. The largest angular scale is sufficient for recovering the bulk of the disk.
The requested sensitivity is such that a nominal carbon abundance will yield roughly a S/N=5-10 detection, while a strong carbon underabundance will yield important upper limits.

The channel spacing of 0.15 km/s will resolve the [CI] velocity structure, as the disk is inclined at ~43 degrees. Although single-dish observations do not suggest there is compact contaminating [CI] emission around the disk (the disk-integrated line profile is double-peaked and symmetric), the kinematics are an important check on the origin of the line.

The angular resolution (0.51'' or 50au at 97pc) is sufficient to distinguish [CI] in the multiple large rings proposed based on ALMA continuum data (15-40au and 155-265au, Walsh et al. 2014). The largest angular scale is chosen to slightly exceed the ALMA-resolved CO emission.

The sensitivity is based on our previous APEX single-dish detection of [CI] 1-0, and will allow on average S/N=10 detections per beam across the disk. Likely, there will be substantial spatial structure in the [CI] emission map, so the peaks will be stronger. The bandwidth will capture the [CI] line as well as the line-free continuum.

The channel spacing of 0.15 km/s will resolve the [CI] velocity structure, as the disk is inclined at ~43 degrees. Although single-dish observations do not suggest there is compact contaminating emission around the disk, the kinematics are an important check on the origin of the line.

The angular resolution (0.51'' or 60au at 120pc) is sufficient to map [CI] across the freezeout zones of important carbon carriers, CO and CH4. The CO ice line has been previously suggested to be at around 110-155au. We expect a substantial underabundance of gas-phase carbon outside this radius, while inside there may be one or more regions within which the abundance is elevated. The largest angular scale corresponds to the size of the disk as seen in optically thick CO emission.

The requested sensitivity is such that a nominal carbon abundance will yield roughly a S/N=5 detection per beam (higher if the emission is more concentrated than we assumed), while a strong carbon underabundance will yield important upper limits. These predictions are based on a grid of DALI disk models for Herbig stars, some of which are shown in Fig.1 and many more in a paper we recently submitted.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In protoplanetary disks, gas-phase carbon can end up locked in ices. This influences the chemical composition of planet-forming solids and of the gas accreted by giant planets. The details of the carbon loss from gas to ices are not yet well understood, nor well constrained observationally. Recent results on the HD 100546 and TW Hya disks suggest that large carbon underabundances can develop even in the warm atmosphere of a disk. The leading hypothesis is that there are large, cold grains settled on the midplane, onto which some fraction of volatiles can freeze when vertically mixed through the midplane. We will use spatially resolved observations of [CI] emission and a state of the art disk modelling code to study carbon freezeout in six disks, resolving the colder outer disk from the warmer inner regions. The targets have been selected to allow a comparison of carbon abundance with fundamental stellar and disk parameters.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: IPAG, Institut de Planetologie et d'Astrophysique de Grenoble
